review.title: Sensitivity analysis in decision circuits
review.abstract: Decision circuits have been developed to perform efficient evaluation of influence diagrams [Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2007], building on the advances in arithmetic circuits for belief network inference [Darwiche,2003]. In the process of model building and analysis, we perform sensitivity analysis to understand how the optimal solution changes in response to changes in the model. When sequential decision problems under uncertainty are represented as decision circuits, we can exploit the efficient solution process embodied in the decision circuit and the wealth of derivative information available to compute the value of information for the uncertainties in the problem and the effects of changes to model parameters on the value and the optimal strategy.

metadata.title: Sensitivity analysis in decision circuits

sections.text: Decision circuits are designed to efficiently evaluate influence diagrams [Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2007], building on advances in arithmetic circuits for faith networks [Darwiche, 2003]. In the process of modelling and analysis, we perform sensitivity analyses to understand how the optimal solution changes in response to changes in the model. If sequential decision problems are presented as decision circuits under uncertainty, we can use the efficient solution process embodied in the decision circuit and the wealth of derived information available to calculate the information value for the uncertainties of the problem and the effects of changes in model parameters on the value and optimal strategy.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Influence diagrams are powerful communication tools and computational tools for analyzing practical decision-making problems [Howard and Matheson, 1984]. Decision circuits are an up-to-date graphical representation introduced for the efficient evaluation of influence diagrams [Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2007]. In this paper, we show that they are also useful for efficient sensitivity analysis in influence diagrams. Generally, the phrase sensitivity analysis refers to understanding how the output for a system varies as a result of changes in the input (s). For influence diagrams, one can think about how the optimal solution and the certain equivalent (CE) will change in terms of changing parameters, i.e. the probabilities and usefulness, or changing the informative assumptions of the problem that we observe are many questions that we can use.

sections.heading: 2 PRELIMINARIES
sections.text: We assume that the reader is familiar with graphical models such as Bayesian Utility Networks and Influence Diagrams (see Shachter (2007) for an overview). Consider the two examples shown in Figure 1. Figure 1a represents a belief network with two nodes, labeled W (weather) and B (bring umbrella). We are interested in knowing if a friend brings an umbrella, and we believe it is easier to model this when we have a state in the weather. Figure 1b shows the influence diagram for a decision problem in which our friend decides whether to bring an umbrella based on their belief in the weather and their preferences, represented by the U node (Utility). She will observe a weather report (R) before making her decision. sections.heading: 4 SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS IN INFLUENCE DIAGRAMS
sections.text: The conditional probabilities in an influence chart can be difficult to assess due to the lack of data, expert judgments on key uncertainties, the inaccuracy of the decision maker in terms of preferences and several other practical reasons. As a result, it is often beneficial to verify the change in the results of the decision model based on variations in the inputs of the model. Such questions fall under the umbrella of sensitivity analysis. Sensitivity analysis is an essential aspect of decision analysis during the development of the field. Sensitivity analysis helps in identifying the critical elements of the model, forms the basis for iterative refinement of the model, and can also be used after analysis to defend a particular strategy to the decision maker. [Howard, 1983] Sensitivity plots the representation of certain equivalents of different strategies can help us to identify the important variables. sections.heading: 5.3 Admissible intervals
sections.text: Another sensitivity question in the sense of a one-way sensitivity analysis is the following: Suppose a certain meta-parameter can vary, while all other meta-parameters remain constant at their reference values. What is the range of this meta-parameter over which the current optimal strategy remains optimal? We call this range the allowable interval for a meta-parameter. In other words, we are investigating how robust the optimal strategy is with regard to all meta-parameters. The allowable intervals are easily obtained for normal shape control diagrams, based on the ideas from the previous subsection. sections.heading: 6.3 Value of information
sections.text: The challenge in conducting information analyses for extensive shape control diagrams is that it is difficult to keep track of all derivatives for all strategies. We propose a simple method to find the value of information for variables that are not influenced by any decision when observed before the first decision. The goal is to reuse the decision circuit formulated in the offline phase. Assuming that the decision circuit has been evaluated and therefore the probability of proof P (e) has already been calculated, we can find the value of the information for each variable X with the help of some upward swings. sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE RESEARCH
sections.text: Decision circuits are a graphical representation for efficient analysis of influence diagrams, with the potential to exploit both the conditional independence in the diagram and the local structure of asymmetries of real decision problems. Newer methods have been developed to create compact circuits using the separability of value function and operations such as circumcision and coalescence [Bhattacharjya and Shachter, 2008]. If the analyst can assemble an efficient decision circuit for an influence diagram, she can then use the compiled circuit to evaluate the optimal strategy and CE before performing sensitivity analyses of the kind depicted in this paper. We examined several one-way sensitivity analyses and demonstrated techniques to answer them using decision circuits. We discussed sensitivity analyses for both normal forms and extensive form influence diagrams. Sensitivity analyses are an essential tool to support critical modelling and assessment of influence diagrams.
